head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #6

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #6 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: which opens So – went in it abt 1½m. Noly & then arrived at the 1st Grand Portage mentd by Mr Lyons of abt 4m. in length, the road is very good, but it took us above 7 hours in passing our things over[.]

June ye 18 Friday. Left ye end of the Portage & went No per compass' in a fine wide opening abt 2m.[,] 2 islds appearing at ye end of ye Course (I found a sudden variation of the compass here of 6 points for when we had turn'd a point were were still going No pt compass, so that I imagine the magnetic needle must be affected by some mineral Ore in ye Earth,) our first Co then was ENE2m. – in River Nippigon (left yesterday) then 3m. to the end of an island – NNW1m. S.C. pass'd it on ye Wt side, from hence NWbN1m. so far this day in a spacious opening – NbW1½m. – No2½m. very high rockey Shores to ye Portage d'Islet 200yds over, Portage on the Wt side, road tolerable – from hence Portage Roché is in a direct line NbE1½m. over an islet in the mide of the River, a water fall on each side, this Portage is 50yds over, & good road – from hence 2d Gand Portage lies NEbN½m. Portage on Wt side & 3m. long. We were not able to pass the whole of our Baggage over this night, tho' it was but 11 o'Clock when we began & ½ after 8 when we gave over[.] This Carrying place is much incommoded with wind fall Trees, but they might be soon clear'd away by a few men with hatchets.

19 Saturday. Brought the remainder of the things over the Portage, & the Inds left a Pais plat overtook us – 1st Course NbE 1 mile to a rapid, which runs out of a Lake with great violence: it requires some Judgment to pass it properly, as the water is thrown very forcibly agt the opposite shore & returns back with equal velocity[.] [T]his opening bore Wt abt 30yds – but we kept our Co No1m. round a Point to Portage Plat – this is 180yds over, & very good road – then No1½m. into a fine spacious opening. The Inds that had been absent from us abt ½ an hour had kill'd sevl fine Jack fish on our arrival: they say they are very numerous here in all the little bays, from hence NWbN1m. to the end of a Bay, left ye river on our right hand, & enter'd a small Creek, very shallow in places & stones above water, much care must be taken of the canoes here (especially if large ones) went in it for abt 1m. Nly & then enter'd a small Lake. Course in it NNW1m. – NWbW4m. to a Portage call'd by the Inds Shoce-co-wap-pe-cau Win-ne-cum, but not mentd in Mr Lyon's Acct abt 1½m. over, the greatest part of the road very Good, at the end of which is Lac Nippigon.
20 Sunday. The Inds that engag'd to Pilot us to Fort Nippigon, wanted

td.p:

in red , modifications made by the editor(s).
in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
